senses.sense: The 1<sup>st</sup> letter of the English alphabet, written in the Latin script.
The ordinal number first, derived from this letter of the English alphabet, called a and written in the Latin script.
The name of the Latin script letter A / a.
One; any indefinite example of.
examples: There was a man here looking for you yesterday.

senses.sense: One; used before score, dozen, hundred, thousand, million, etc.
examples: I've seen it happen a hundred times.

senses.sense: Used in some phrases denoting quantity, such as a few, a good many, a couple, a little (for an uncountable noun), etc.
examples: They asked me a few questions.

senses.sense: Used in some adverbial phrases denoting degree or extent, such as a little, a bit, a lot, etc.
examples: The door was opened a little.

senses.sense: The same; one and the same. Used in phrases such as of a kind, birds of a feather, etc.
examples: We are of a mind on matters of morals.
They're two of a kind.

senses.sense: Any; every; used before a noun which has become modified to limit its scope.
examples: A man who dies intestate leaves his children troubles and difficulties.

senses.sense: Any; used with a negative to indicate not a single one.
examples: It was so dark that we couldn't see a thing.
He fell all that way, and hasn't a bump on his head?

senses.sense: Used before an adjective that modifies a noun (singular or plural) delimited by a numeral.
examples: a staggering three million dollars
The holidays are a mere one week away.

senses.sense: One; someone named; used before a person's name, suggesting that the speaker knows little about the person other than the name.
examples: We've received an interesting letter from a Mrs. Miggins of London.

senses.sense: Used before an adjective modifying a person's name.
Someone or something like; similar to; Used before a proper noun to create an example out of it.
examples: The center of the village was becoming a Times Square.
The man is a regular Romeo.

senses.sense: To do with separation; In, into.
examples: Torn a pieces.

senses.sense: To do with time; Each, per, in, on, by. Often occurs between two nouns, where the first noun occurs at the end of a verbal phrase.
examples: I brush my teeth twice a day.

senses.sense: To do with status; In.
(archaic) To do with position or direction; In, on, at, by, towards, onto.
examples: Stand a tiptoe.

senses.sense: (archaic) To do with process, with a passive verb; In the course of, experiencing.
(archaic) To do with an action, an active verb; Engaged in.
(archaic) To do with an action/movement; To, into.
(obsolete) To do with method; In, with.
(obsolete) To do with role or capacity; In.
examples: A God’s name.

senses.sense: (archaic or slang) Have.
senses.date: between 1150 and 1350, continued in some use until 1650; used again after 1950
examples: I'd a come, if you'd a asked.
Oi'd a gen im a clout, if oi'd been theer. from Robert Holland, M.R.A.C., A Glossary of Words Used in the County of Chester, Part I--A to F., English Dialect Society, London, 1884, 1

senses.sense: (obsolete, outside England and Scotland dialects) He, or sometimes she, it.
(archaic or slang) Of.
examples: The name of John a Gaunt.

senses.sense: (chiefly Scotland) All.
(chiefly Scotland) All.
Distance from leading edge to aerodynamic center.
specific absorption coefficient
specific rotation
allele (recessive)
(crosswords) across
examples: Do you have the answer for 23a?

senses.sense: (chiefly US) Alternative spelling of a.m. ("ante meridiem") or am
Alternative form of -a ("empty syllable added to songs, poetry, verse and other speech")
The name of the Cyrillic script letter А / а.
ah; er (sound of hesitation)
